headline.main: More About the Budget and Health

docs.abstract: How can technology help us eat better?
docs.lead_paragraph: Here’s the article by David Ludwig about the relationship between technology and diet that started me down this path in the first place. Really good reading, and not at all technical. (The clinic that Ludwig runs at Children’s Hospital in Boston is dedicated to the evaluation and treatment of children who are overweight/obese and/or those with type 2 diabetes.)
docs.snippet: How can technology help us eat better?

headline.main: Talk to Gary Taubes About Sugar

docs.abstract: Health writer Gary Taubes responds to reader questions about sugar and why we get fat.
docs.lead_paragraph: In this week's New York Times Magazine, Gary Taubes, author most recently of "Why We Get Fat: And What to Do About It," takes on sugar. Among other things, he writes about the views of Robert Lustig, an obesity expert at the University of California, San Francisco, School of Medicine.
docs.snippet: Health writer Gary Taubes responds to reader questions about sugar and why we get fat.

headline.main: How to Save a Trillion Dollars

docs.abstract: As Congress tries to get the budget under control, it's worth noting the fiscal toll of treating "lifestyle diseases."
docs.lead_paragraph: In the scheme of things, saving the 38 billion bucks that Congress seems poised to agree upon is not a big deal. A big deal is saving a trillion bucks. And we could do that by preventing disease instead of treating it.
docs.snippet: As Congress tries to get the budget under control, it's worth noting the fiscal toll of treating "lifestyle diseases."

headline.seo: In Orthodox Jewish Enclaves, an Alarm Sounds Over Eating Disorders
headline.print_headline: Rabbis Sound an Alarm Over Eating Disorders
headline.main: Rabbis Sound an Alarm Over Eating Disorders

docs.lead_paragraph: Pressure to marry young and be all things to all people contributes to a problem, rabbinic leaders say, and a stigma against mental health problems complicates treatment.
docs.snippet: Pressure to marry young and be all things to all people contributes to a problem, rabbinic leaders say, and a stigma against mental health problems complicates treatment.

docs.abstract: Medicare and Medicaid spending remain in the spotlight.
docs.lead_paragraph: While Congress and the Obama administration averted a government shutdown late last week, federal lawmakers and presidential aides will continue to debate how to cut spending -- with Medicare and Medicaid often in the cross hairs.
docs.snippet: Medicare and Medicaid spending remain in the spotlight.
